Determine Non‑Uniform Columns via Distance Measures

Source: R/Rinternal.R
iskept.Rd

Identifies which columns of a probability matrix deviate from the uniform distribution by computing a chosen distance metric and splitting the distances into two clusters.

Arguments

prob_mat

Numeric \(n \times m\) matrix of probabilities (each column sums to 1).

method

Character; one of "tv", "js", "hellinger", "l2", "chi2", "kl", "kolmogorov", or "wasserstein".

Value

Logical vector of length \(m\), where TRUE indicates a column is deemed non‑uniform.

Details

Given a probability matrix prob_mat of dimension \(n \times m\) whose columns sum to 1, this function computes, for each column \(j\), a distance \(d_j\) between prob_mat[, j] and the uniform distribution \(u = (1/n, \dots, 1/n)\). Supported metrics are total variation, Jensen–Shannon divergence, Hellinger distance, L2 distance, Chi‑squared, Kullback–Leibler divergence, Kolmogorov–Smirnov statistic, and 1st‑Wasserstein distance. The distances \(\{d_1,\dots,d_m\}\) are then clustered via \(k=2\) k‑means and the cluster with the larger mean is marked “non‑uniform.” If clustering fails, a maximum‑gap threshold on the sorted distances is used instead.

Examples

# A 5×3 probability matrix
P <- matrix(c(
  0.2, 0.33, 0.10,
  0.2, 0.33, 0.20,
  0.2, 0.33, 0.30,
  0.2, 0.01, 0.30,
  0.2, 0.00, 0.10
), nrow = 5, byrow = TRUE)
iskept(P, method = "js")
#> [1] FALSE  TRUE FALSE
